chapter: Diabetes Mellitus  Complications and their Mana

questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is not a feature of diabetic ketoacidosis?
questions.explanation:
In diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), serum bicarbonate is usually < 15. Serum HCO3 > 15 meq/L 
is suggestive of alcoholic ketoacidosis. DKA is an acute complication of type 1 diabetes mellitus. It is usually precipitated by absolute or 
relative insulin deficiency caused by increased metabolic demand (infections) or insulin 
noncompliance. The common symptoms include nausea, vomiting, and severe abdominal pain. The common signs 
include Kussmaul breathing, fruity odor of the breath, dehydration, tachycardia, hypotension, 
and delirium. The diagnosis of DKA is made based on the following parameters: • Hyperglycemia > 250 mg/dl • Ketosis or ketones in urine • Metabolic acidosis with pH < 7.3 • HCO3 < 15-18 mEq/L • High anion gap due to ketoacids and lactic acidosis Hyponatremia is seen as a result of hyperglycemia (osmotic shift causes dilutional hyponatremia). 
Normal sodium levels on admission indicate severe dehydration. Despite a total-body potassium 
deficit, the serum Potassium at presentation may be mildly elevated, secondary to the acidosis and 
volume depletion.
questions.chapter_heading: Diabetes Mellitus  Complications and their Mana

questions.question:
Question 2: A 19-year-old woman with a history of type 1 diabetes is brought to the ER with confusion, 
vomiting, and abdominal pain. Investigations show blood glucose of 520 mg/dl and urine 
positive for ketone bodies. Which of the following is the drug of choice?
questions.explanation:
The drug of choice for controlling hyperglycemia in a patient with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is 
short-acting insulin, preferably regular insulin. 196 
Sold by @itachibot Intermediate (such as lente insulin and NPH), long-acting insulins, and oral hypoglycemic agents 
are never used in the initial management of DKA. The mainstay of treatment is the administration of normal saline followed by infusion of 
short-acting insulin. The precipitating event must be identified and treated. Careful monitoring 
of K+ levels and replacement in the later stages is required, as insulin therapy causes 
hypokalemia.
questions.chapter_heading: Diabetes Mellitus  Complications and their Mana

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following is the leading cause of death in children with diabetic ketoacidosis?
questions.explanation:
Cerebral edema is the leading cause of mortality in children with diabetic ketoacidosis. The osmolar gradient generated due to the high blood glucose level results in water shift from the 
intracellular fluid (ICF) to the extracellular fluid (ECF) space and leads to the contraction of cell 
volume. Correction with insulin and intravenous fluids can result in a rapid reduction in effective 
osmolarity, reversal of the fluid shift, and result in cerebral edema. Complications of diabetic ketoacidosis include: • Cerebral edema – especially in children • Cardiac arrhythmia - due to electrolyte imbalance • Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) • Venous thrombosis • Acute gastric dilation • Acute kidney injury • Intestinal necrosis • Acute pancreatitis • Mucormycosis
questions.chapter_heading: Diabetes Mellitus  Complications and their Mana

questions.question:
Question 4: A patient with diabetic ketoacidosis has severe abdominal pain. Which of the following is the 
recommended test to rule out acute pancreatitis? 187 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
In diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), severe abdominal pain can mimic acute pancreatitis. Serum lipase 
is the best test to rule out this condition. It must then be confirmed by imaging (USG or CT 
abdomen). Serum amylase is an unreliable indicator as DKA is associated with hyperamylasemia of salivary 
origin. Serum and urine trypsinogen may be elevated in early pancreatitis but are not used for diagnosis. 
Fecal elastase is elevated in chronic pancreatitis.
questions.chapter_heading: Diabetes Mellitus  Complications and their Mana

questions.question:
Question 5: A 15-year old boy presents with persistent vomiting for one day. Laboratory investigations 
reveal the following. What is the best sequence of management?

options.a: Start IV fluids, administer IV regular insulin, and then correct hypokalemia
options.b: Start IV fluids, administer subcutaneous bolus of insulin and correct hypokalemia concurrently
options.c: Start IV fluids and correct hypokalemia first, then administer IV regular insulin
options.d: Administer IV regular insulin with KCl first , then start IV fluids once the K+ level is corrected

questions.explanation:
197 
Sold by @itachibot This clinical scenario is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). On confirming the diagnosis, IV 
fluids must be started. If the initial serum potassium < 3.3 meq/L, insulin should be 
administered only after the correction of hypokalemia. This is because treatment with insulin and fluids can worsen hypokalemia by the following 
mechanisms: • Insulin causes the shift of K+ ions into cells • Resolution of the acidosis also promotes K+ entry into cells • Urinary loss of K+ salts of organic acids
questions.chapter_heading: Diabetes Mellitus  Complications and their Mana

questions.question:
Question 6: Distinguishing features between hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state and diabetic ketoacidosis 
include all of the following except:
questions.explanation:
Hypotension and tachycardia are common features of both hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state 
(HHS) and diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). In DKA, insulin deficiency and an increase in counter-regulatory hormones lead to shunting of 
free fatty acids to form ketone bodies. The ketoacids increase the anion gap and cause low pH. In 
HHS, there is still some insulin available. Hence, there are no ketones formed, and the patient 
has normal pH and pCO2.
questions.chapter_heading: Diabetes Mellitus  Complications and their Mana

questions.question:
Question 7: An elderly man is brought to the hospital with confusion and drowsiness. His son says that he 
has been urinating more frequently than normal and eating very little over the past 1 week. 
Capillary blood glucose is 800 mg/dl. Which of the following would not be seen in this 
patient?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state (HHS). Kussmaul's 
breathing is not a feature of HHS. HHS is commonly seen in older adults suffering from type 2 diabetes mellitus. Patients can 
present with the following features: • Polyuria 198 
Sold by @itachibot • Polydipsia • Lethargy • Altered sensorium, coma • Seizures • Severe dehydration The following lab values are seen: • Blood glucose of 600-1200 mg/dl • Serum osmolality > 350 mOsm/L • Prerenal azotemia due to dehydration • Pseudohyponatremia may be seen due to hyperglycemia • Normal pH and ketones The mainstay of management is fluid replacement, IV regular insulin, along with potassium 
replacement. Heparin can be given prophylactically as volume contraction can increase the risk of venous 
thrombosis.
questions.chapter_heading: Diabetes Mellitus  Complications and their Mana

questions.question: Question 8: What is the most common pattern of dyslipidemia associated with diabetes mellitus?
questions.explanation:
Dyslipidemia commonly occurs as a complication of type 2 diabetes mellitus. The most common 
pattern is as follows: • Increased triglyceride levels - due to increased glucose and free fatty acids, decreased lipolysis of 
VLDL. • Decreased HDL levels Though diabetes does not increase LDL levels, there is increased atherogenicity as the existing 
LDL molecules are more easily glycated and susceptible to oxidation.
questions.chapter_heading: Diabetes Mellitus  Complications and their Mana

questions.question: Question 9: Dyslipidemia is more commonly associated with which of the following?

options.c: Maturity onset diabetes of the young

questions.explanation:
Dyslipidemia is more commonly associated with type 2 diabetes mellitus. It is less common in type 1 and gestational diabetes. Maturity onset diabetes of the young (MODY) 
is not associated with dyslipidemia. Note: Saroglitazar is a more advanced drug that reduces blood sugar and lipid levels in diabetic 
patients. It acts on PPAR alpha and gamma receptors.
questions.chapter_heading: Diabetes Mellitus  Complications and their Mana

questions.question:
Question 10: You have started a 40-year-old man on treatment for type 2 diabetes mellitus and 
dyslipidemia. Which of the following is not an appropriate target for this patient?
questions.explanation:
199 
Sold by @itachibot According to the ADA guidelines, a treatment goal of postprandial plasma glucose < 180 mg/dL 
must be followed in adults with diabetes. In younger individuals or those with other cardiovascular risk factors, the target blood pressure is 
< 130/80 mm Hg. Although not a treatment goal, the ADA also recommends triglyceride levels 
be maintained at < 150 mg/dl. Note: Saroglitazar is a more advanced drug that reduces blood sugar and lipid levels in diabetic 
patients. It acts on PPAR alpha and gamma receptors.
questions.chapter_heading: Diabetes Mellitus  Complications and their Mana

questions.question:
Question 11: A middle-aged patient with type 2 diabetes is diagnosed with essential hypertension. What is 
the antihypertensive drug of choice?
questions.explanation:
The drug of choice in this diabetic patient with hypertension is losartan. Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE inhibitors) or angiotensin receptor blockers 
(ARB) are the first-line drugs in diabetic hypertensives. Among ARBs, the drug of choice is 
telmisartan (acts on PPAR receptor). They reduce both macrovascular and microvascular complications and have a nephroprotective 
effect. However, they are contraindicated in chronic kidney disease as they can cause a further 
decline in GFR.
questions.chapter_heading: Diabetes Mellitus  Complications and their Mana

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following is the earliest manifestation of diabetic nephropathy?
questions.explanation:
The earliest manifestation of diabetic nephropathy is an increase in the glomerular filtration rate 
(GFR). It occurs as a result of glomerular hyperperfusion and renal hypertrophy. The following sequence 
of changes are seen in diabetic nephropathy: • Increased GFR • Incipient diabetic nephropathy - microalbuminuria (30–300 mg/day albumin) • Diagnostic marker to detect early diabetic nephropathy • Indicator of long-term cardiovascular disease • Overt diabetic nephropathy - macroalbuminuria ( >300 mg/day albumin) • End-stage renal disease 200 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Diabetes Mellitus  Complications and their Mana

questions.question:
Question 13: A 15-year-old boy has been on treatment for type 1 diabetes mellitus since the age of 10 years. 
His physician decides to begin screening for diabetic nephropathy. Which of the following is 
not always a reliable indicator of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Albumin of 30-300 mg/day refers to microalbuminuria. It can be unreliable in 
the diagnosis of diabetic nephropathy. It is not required to diagnose nephropathy as it is very variable. Non-albuminuric diabetic 
nephropathy may occur in some patients and regression of albuminuria may be seen in type 1 
diabetics. Diabetic nephropathy can be diagnosed if the following are satisfied: • Reduced GFR (< 60 mL/min/1.73 m2) with or without persistent albuminuria (> 30 mg/day 
or urine PCR > 30 mg/g) • Long duration of diabetes or established diabetic retinopathy • Other etiologies are ruled out Long duration in type 1 diabetes refers to 5 years after diagnosis. On the other hand, patients with 
type 2 diabetes are exposed to hyperglycemia and prediabetes for a long time even before 
diagnosis. Hence, at the time of diagnosis, patients with type 2 diabetes are considered to have 
had the disorder for a duration sufficiently long to produce kidney disease. However, a clinical diagnosis of diabetic nephropathy can be made in patients with established 
retinopathy, even if the duration of diabetes is short.
questions.chapter_heading: Diabetes Mellitus  Complications and their Mana

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following statements about diabetic nephropathy is true?

options.a: Pancreatic transplantation can improve proteinuria at an early stage
options.b: Strict glycemic control is unlikely to prevent microalbuminuria
options.c: Dietary protein restriction can benefit diabetic patients with albuminuria
options.d: Microalbuminuria is not an indicator of long-term cardiovascular morbidity

questions.explanation:
Pancreatic transplantation can help improve proteinuria at an early stage. Successful pancreatic 
transplantation can have the following effects: • Prevention of diabetic nephropathy and regression of albuminuria in early stages. 201 
Sold by @itachibot • Stabilization and improvement of diabetic neuropathy and retinopathy • Increase in HDL with reduction in LDL and triglycerides Option B: Strict glycemic control can prevent or revert microalbuminuria. Option C: The ADA does not suggest restrictions of protein intake in diabetic patients with 
albuminuria because studies have failed to prove its benefits. Option D: Microalbuminuria is an indicator of long-term cardiovascular morbidity.
questions.chapter_heading: Diabetes Mellitus  Complications and their Mana

questions.question:
Question 15: A 50-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus is found to have a 24-hour urinary albumin 
of 250 mg. Which of the following drugs may be prescribed to reduce the progression of this 
condition?
questions.explanation:
Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACEI) inhibitors or angiotensin-receptor blockers (ARB) are 
recommended to reduce the progression of diabetic nephropathy. It has the following effects: • Reduction of albuminuria • Reduces the associated decline in GFR The mainstay of management of diabetic nephropathy includes control of blood sugar and blood 
pressure, inhibitors of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone(RAAS) system, and inhibitors of SGLT2 
to halt the progression of the disease. RAAS inhibitors include ACE inhibitors, ARBs, or direct renin inhibitors.
questions.chapter_heading: Diabetes Mellitus  Complications and their Mana

questions.question:
Question 16: A pathologist is studying a renal biopsy sample from a patient with suspected diabetic 
nephropathy. Which of the following biopsy findings is pathognomonic for this condition?
questions.explanation:
The characteristic lesion of diabetic nephropathy is nodular or intercapillary glomerulosclerosis, 
also called Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules. It is pathognomonic for this condition. The following image shows Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules. Other non-specific findings seen on biopsy include: 202 
Sold by @itachibot • Glomerular basement membrane (GBM) thickening - highly sensitive • Diffuse glomerulosclerosis - most common pattern, due to diffuse mesangial thickening • Fibrin cap - accumulation of hyaline material within the capillary loop • Capsular drop - accumulation of hyaline material attached to the Bowman's capsule • Armani-Ebstein reaction - collection of glycogen clumps within the renal tubules due to tubular 
injury Renal biopsy is done to rule out other causes of renal failure. The indications for renal biopsy in 
diabetic nephropathy are: • Absence of diabetic retinopathy • Absence of edema • Absence of frothing and proteinuria • Absence of hypertension • Presence of microscopic hematuria or features of nephritic syndrome
questions.chapter_heading: Diabetes Mellitus  Complications and their Mana

questions.question:
Question 17: Which of the following types of renal tubular acidosis can develop in individuals with diabetes 
mellitus?
questions.explanation:
Type IV renal tubular acidosis (RTA) may occur in individuals with diabetes mellitus types 1 and 
2. Type IV RTA occurs due to hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism. Low plasma renin activity is 
common in diabetic patients due to: • Impaired conversion of prorenin to renin • Volume expansion in diabetic nephropathy suppresses renin release These individuals have a tendency to develop hyperkalemia and acidemia, which can be 
exacerbated by the use of ACEI and ARBs. Hence, these drugs should be avoided.
questions.chapter_heading: Diabetes Mellitus  Complications and their Mana

questions.question:
Question 18: A 45-year-old man has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus. When should you refer 
him to an ophthalmologist?

options.b: Immediately at the time of diagnosis

questions.explanation:
Patients with type 2 diabetes should undergo a comprehensive ophthalmological examination to 
screen for diabetic retinopathy at diagnosis, followed by an annual examination of the fundus. In patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus, screening for retinopathy is recommended 3 to 5 years 
after diagnosis. Annual fundal examination is recommended thereafter.
questions.chapter_heading: Diabetes Mellitus  Complications and their Mana

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following patients would you screen for diabetic retinopathy?
questions.explanation:
Screening for diabetic retinopathy is done at 3-5 years following diagnosis in type 1 diabetes 
mellitus, whereas, patients with type 2 diabetes must be screened at the time of diagnosis. 203 
Sold by @itachibot As type 2 diabetes mellitus often has a long asymptomatic period of hyperglycemia before clinical 
diagnosis, these patients are more likely to have complications at the time of diagnosis itself. Retinopathy develops in nearly 50-80% of patients by 20 years of diagnosis. The presence of 
diabetic retinopathy often correlates with pathological findings of diabetic nephropathy.
questions.chapter_heading: Diabetes Mellitus  Complications and their Mana

questions.question: Question 20: What is the most common clinical presentation of diabetic neuropathy?
questions.explanation:
The most common form of diabetic neuropathy is distal symmetric polyneuropathy. It presents 
with distal sensory loss and pain in a stocking-and-glove distribution and is a risk factor for foot 
ulceration. Autonomic neuropathy is a common complication and results in the following features: • Postural hypotension • Silent myocardial infarction • Hypoglycemia unawareness • Erectile dysfunction • Overflow incontinence • Gastroparesis • Enteropathy with constipation or diarrhea Mononeuropathy of peripheral (median, ulnar, radial) and cranial (oculomotor) nerves is also 
seen, as well as mononeuritis multiplex. Diabetic polyradiculopathy is characterized by severe pain along the distribution of one or more 
nerve roots.
questions.chapter_heading: Diabetes Mellitus  Complications and their Mana

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following findings in a diabetic patient is self-limiting?
questions.explanation:
Amyotrophy refers to weakness of hip extensors and flexors secondary to polyradiculopathy 
involving the lumbar plexus and femoral nerve. It is associated with severe pain along the 
distribution of the nerve roots. It is self-limiting and resolves over 6-12 months. Strict glycemic control can reduce the incidence and prevent the progression of macular edema, 
peripheral neuropathy, and macroalbuminuria. However, once developed, they cannot be 
reversed. Intermittent microalbuminuria with normal GFR can be reversed with strict glycemic 
control.
questions.chapter_heading: Diabetes Mellitus  Complications and their Mana

questions.question:
Question 22: You are evaluating a 65-year-old diabetic woman who has been admitted following a seizure. 
On admission, she was unconscious, and random blood glucose at admission was 37 mg/dl. 
The hypoglycemia was corrected and she regained consciousness. The woman says that she 
had felt normal and had no other symptoms prior to the onset of seizures. What is the likely 
cause of this presentation?

options.a: Medication change from metformin to insulin

questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of silent hypoglycemia in a diabetic patient. The most likely 
cause is autonomic neuropathy. 204 
Sold by @itachibot Hypoglycemia presents with symptoms like palpitation, tremors, and sweating as a result 
of sympathetic stimulation. These symptoms are protective and provide advance warning before 
progression to neuroglucopenia. However, in autonomic neuropathy, there is a reduced release of counterregulatory hormones 
like catecholamines. Hence, the classical symptoms of hypoglycemia do not occur and the patient 
directly presents with features of neuroglucopenia. This is called hypoglycemia unawareness. The use of beta-blockers can also cause hypoglycemia unawareness.
questions.chapter_heading: Diabetes Mellitus  Complications and their Mana

questions.question:
Question 23: 192 
Sold by @itachibot You are counselling a patient with longstanding, poorly-controlled diabetes mellitus. Advising 
tight glycemic control in this patient would not improve which of the following?
questions.explanation:
In patients with longstanding diabetes mellitus, tight glycaemic control is beneficial 
for microvascular complications. However, it has no effect on macrovascular complications like 
peripheral vascular disease (PVD), myocardial infarction, and stroke. Good glycemic control improves microvascular complications through primary and secondary 
prevention. It reduces the incidence of complications as well as stabilizes and prevents further 
progression in affected individuals. Intermittent microalbuminuria with normal GFR can even be 
reversed with tight glycemic control. Complication 
% risk reduction with tight gl

47 % 39 % Microalbumin

questions.chapter_heading: Diabetes Mellitus  Complications and their Mana

questions.question: Question 24: Which among the following statements explains Legacy effect and metabolic memory?
questions.explanation:
Legacy effect or metabolic memory can be observed in relation to glycemic control during early 
disease in patients with diabetes mellitus. Intensive glycemic control during the early stages of the disease has a positive effect on long-term 
microvascular and macrovascular complications (statement 1) even if this intensive glycemic 
control is not maintained long term. Similarly, uncontrolled blood glucose levels in the early 
stages causes an increased risk of these complications (statement 5). This phenomenon is called 
legacy effect and is attributed to metabolic memory. In patients with longstanding diabetes, intensive glycemic control at later stages can improve 
microvascular complications but has no effect on macrovascular complications. 205 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Diabetes Mellitus  Complications and their Mana

questions.question:
Question 25: A patient with chronic diabetes presents to the OPD for his annual checkup. A small painless 
ulcer is noted over his right foot. His BMI is 33 kg/m2. All of the following factors can be 
implicated in the causation of his foot ulcer except:
questions.explanation:
Venous stasis is not a cause of diabetic foot ulcers and gangrene. They are usually caused by a 
combination of three factors: • Ischemia - secondary to atheroma • Peripheral neuropathy - leads to trophic skin changes • Immunosuppression - due to excess sugar deposition in tissues, predisposing diabetic patients to 
infection Common sites of ulcers include: • Great toe • Metatarsophalangeal areas.
questions.chapter_heading: Diabetes Mellitus  Complications and their Mana

questions.question:
Question 26: A 25-year-old diabetic woman presents to the OPD with the following skin lesions. What is 
the likely diagnosis? 193 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image showing irregular plaques with yellowish discoloration and telangiectasias are 
suggestive of necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum. It is an inflammatory granulomatous disorder of the skin due to collagen degeneration and lipid 
deposition. It is usually seen in young women with diabetes mellitus. The lesions usually begin in the pretibial region. It begins as papules that gradually enlarge and 
darken to form erythematous plaques with irregular margins, atrophic centers, and central 
ulceration. Option A: Necrolytic migratory erythema is a feature of glucagonoma. It is a waxing and waning 
rash that appears as shown below. Option B: Diabetic dermopathy or shin spots are commonly seen in elderly men. It presents as 
pigmented pretibial papules as shown below. 206 
Sold by @itachibot Option D: Granuloma annulare presents with small papules arranged in an annular pattern. There 
is no yellowish discoloration or telangiectasias, as shown below.
questions.chapter_heading: Diabetes Mellitus  Complications and their Mana

questions.question:
Question 27: Patients with diabetes mellitus are at a higher risk of developing all of the following infections 
except:
questions.explanation:
Emphysematous appendicitis is not a complication of diabetes mellitus. The potentially 
fatal infectious complications of diabetes include: • Malignant otitis externa • Rhinocerebral mucormycosis • Emphysematous pyelonephritis • Emphysematous cholecystitis 207 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Diabetes Mellitus  Complications and their Mana

questions.question:
Question 28: A morbidly obese diabetic woman is not responsive to metformin therapy. She has a history 
of pancreatitis and family history of bladder cancer. She does not want to take injections. 
Which of the following would be suitable to reduce her glucose levels?
questions.explanation:
Among the given options, canagliflozin (Option C) is the most suitable treatment. It is an oral 
drug belonging to the class SGLT-2 inhibitors and causes weight loss. Although it increases the 
risk of urogenital infections, it has no risk of pancreatitis or bladder cancer. Option A: Sitagliptin, a DPP-IV inhibitor, is associated with the risk of acute pancreatitis. Option B: Pioglitazone, a thiazolidinedione, can increase the risk of bladder cancer and can cause 
weight gain and congestive cardiac failure. Option D: Liraglutide is an injectable GLP-1 receptor agonist. Pancreatitis is a serious adverse 
effect of this drug. Hence, it is contraindicated in individuals with a history of pancreatitis and 
should be permanently discontinued if pancreatitis develops.
questions.chapter_heading: Diabetes Mellitus  Complications and their Mana

questions.question:
Question 29: Which of the following anti-diabetic drugs should be stopped in a patient with a creatinine of 
5.6 mg/dL?
questions.explanation:
Metformin should be stopped in case of elevated creatinine levels (renal insufficiency) > 1.5 
mg/dl in men and >1.4 mg/dl in women. Metformin acts by reducing hepatic glucose production and improves peripheral glucose 
utilization. Lactic acidosis and Vitamin B12 deficiency are specific adverse effects of metformin. It 
is not used in patients with a glomerular filtration rate <30 mL/min (moderate renal 
insufficiency), acidosis, unstable congestive cardiac failure, liver disease, severe hypoxemia, and 
patients undergoing contrast studies. 208 
Sold by @itachibot Reproductive Endocrinology
